metadata.why_i_like_it: Timeless piece. Describes the mission of investing and building, and captures the feeling when it's working and when it's not, without listing a metric. I re-read it a couple times a year.

formatted_content.html:
And you can always feel product/market fit when it's happening.

The customers are buying the product just as fast as you can make it—or usage is growing just as fast as you can add more servers. Money from customers is piling up in your company checking account.

You're hiring sales and customer support staff as fast as you can. Reporters are calling because they've heard about your hot new thing and they want to talk to you about it. You start getting entrepreneur of the year awards from Harvard Business School. Investment bankers are staking out your house.

metadata.why_i_like_it: The opening verse of the Dhammapada — the first teaching in one of Buddhism's foundational texts. K.R. Norman's translation is the Pali Text Society's preferred version, and it captures something the popular paraphrases miss: there's no "self" being created here, just a precise observation about how experience arises moment-to-moment. Mind precedes. Mind leads. Mind makes. What you attend to shapes what you experience. I first encountered this sentiment in a Peloton meditation — "you see more of what you focus on" — and traced it back here.
